awd_titl_txt: Group Travel for U.S. Participants in the XVII World Congress of Sociology, Gothenburg, Sweden, July 11-17, 2010
awd_abstract_narration:
SES- 0852624
Sally Hillsman
American Sociological Association


This travel grant supports U.S. sociologists to attend the XVIIth World Congress of the International Sociological Association (ISA) in Gothenburg, Sweden, July 11-17, 2010. The ISA is the major international organization of sociologists, and the World Congress is the single most important opportunity for U.S. sociologists to exchange ideas and scholarship and promote collaborations on an international scale. The World Congress, which includes hundreds of sessions, exhibits, and other events, occurs at four year intervals and attracts approximately 5,000 participants from around the world. Support for travel of U.S. sociologists permits continued growth of international exchange and collaboration in sociology and ensures a strong presence of U.S. scholars in this important venue. The meeting promotes international collaborations on a wide range of challenges arising from global social processes and transformations, including those stemming from global interconnectedness, worldwide social problems, and environmental concerns that transcend national boundaries.

GROUP TRAVEL FOR U.S. PARTICIPANTS IN THE XVII WORLD CONGRESS OF SOCIOLOGY, GOTHENBURG, SWEDEN

JULY 11-17, 2010

SES-0852624

 Project Outcome Report (POR)

This project provided competitively awarded travel funds to enable U.S. sociologists to attend the XVIIth World Congress of the International Sociological Association (ISA) in Gothenburg Sweden, from July 11-17, 2010. The American Sociological Association (ASA) was awarded a grant of $66,000 by the National Science Foundation (NSF) in January 2010 for this purpose. The ISA World Congress is convened only once every four years. Travel support thus ensures that U.S. sociologists have a strong presence in this important international conference. The ASA has applied for and received block grants in support of travel to the ISA World Congress meetings since the early 1980s.

The ISA is the major international organization of sociologists, and the World Congress is therefore a unique opportunity for U.S. sociologists to present their latest research, exchange ideas and scholarship, and engage formally and informally with scholars from around the world. Founded in 1949 under the auspices of UNESCO, the ISA represents sociologists from more than 160 countries around the world and seeks to advance sociological knowledge worldwide. The 2010 World Congress in Gothenburg drew more than 5,000 participants (with more than 500 from the U.S.) from about 100 countries for presentations in panels, workshops, and other venues.

The Executive Office of the ASA administers the NSF award, including placing of announcements for the competition, acceptance of applications, evaluation of individual requests for travel support, selection of recipients, and the distribution of funds. During 2009 and early 2010, the ASA Executive Office widely disseminated a call for applications for the travel support competition. At the close of the competition on March 15, 2010, 142 individuals submitted applications for travel support (the largest ever pool of applicants for ISA travel support sponsored by ASA with NSF funding). The applicants were a diverse group, representing individuals from all career stages, types of institutions, and geographic locations across the nation.

Awards were determined through a peer review of the applications, which focused primarily on the nature, significance, and merit of the paper to be presented or of the role of the applicant in the program of the World Congress. The ASA Executive Office established a Travel Grant Selection Committee comprised of sociological scholars, which had the responsibility for reviewing, evaluating, and ranking applications for the travel grants. While scientific merit and contribution of the paper (or role) in the program were the key criteria for evaluation of the applications, reviewers also paid attention to balancing applicant qualifications so that scholars at all levels of experience (graduate students, junior sociologists) and sociologists of color, women sociologists, and sociologists with disabilities would receive travel support. This travel support thus advances the scholarship of those who might not otherwise have an opportunity to attend an international meeting focused on scientific exchange and collaboration on issues of international significance.

In the 2010 competition, 65 applicants (or 46 percent of the applicant pool) received travel support awards. Graduate students and postdoctoral candidates, minority, and women applicants all received awards at higher rates than their representation in the applicant pool.  Project Outcome Report (POR)

This project provided competitively awarded travel funds to enable U.S. sociologists to attend the XVIIth World Congress of the International Sociological Association (ISA) in Gothenburg Sweden, from July 11-17, 2010. The American Sociological Association (ASA) was awarded a grant of $66,000 by the National Science Foundation (NSF) in January 2010 for this purpose. In the 2010 competition, 65 applicants (or 46 percent of the applicant pool) received travel support awards. Graduate students and postdoctoral candidates, minority, and women applicants all received awards at higher rates than their representation in the applicant pool. Almost half of the awardees came from large research universities (as determined by the directory of the American Association of Universities), and the remainder was affiliated with other types of colleges and universities, research institutes, and other programs. Awardees came from 25 states and 2 foreign locations (i.e., U.S. sociologists currently and temporarily residing outside the US). The average award was $925.
